intro: Christella quadrangularis, commonly known as the four-cornered mallow, is a herbaceous plant native to the southern United States. It features square, hairy stems that are characteristic of the Malvaceae family. The plant produces small, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a rough texture. Christella quadrangularis is typically found in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and in open woodlands.
